From: "Mathieu Gervais" <egoine_@...>

Hi Thomas,

>As a matter of fact VisualAge Websphere Test environment is a real snail &
lookups can take sometimes many seconds.

Are you aware that you aren't forced to use instantDB for the data source of
the persistent name server?
The PNS can be configured to use db2, for example, and name resolution
should then be much faster. Also you can try to shorten your JNDI name (less
"/" in them), because the naming service does a "hop" for every "/" in the
binding name. The default JDNI name for EJB that uses the fully qualified
class name can be pretty long.

mathieu

----- Original Message -----
From: tsmets@...
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Tuesday, July 17, 2001 2:45 AM
Subject: [junit] JunitPerf


I'm currently trying to make a JunitPerf to be able to monitor the
NamingService response time (for EJB's development). As a matter of fact
VisualAge Websphere Test environment is a real snail & lookups can take
sometimes many seconds. My problem is the fact that the potential real issue
is the latency in the response.

I was wandering if someone could help in defining a way to avoid the
overhead of the System.currentTimemillis() coded in the JunitPerf. On the
production environment the biggest part of the response time is divided in
three parts - believe - :
  1. CurrentTime access
  2. Naming access
  3. CurrentTime access

To reduce the influence of the timing, I can loop the Naming Access, but
then I get the caching kicking in.

If someone had an hint to keep the test as simple as possible (no looping on
all the Names to access)...

Tx,

Thomas,
subject: Re: [junit] JunitPerf - VAJ  [OT]
